questions.prompt: Do people make APPOINTMENTS to see doctors?
Is a dollar adequate COMPENSATION for painting a house?
Should people be DUMBFOUNDED if the sun rises in the morning?
Is stealing money an ELEVATING experience?
Is it polite to ACKNOWLEDGE a favor that someone has done for you?
Does it take less time to read a book if it has been CONDENSED?
Are judges supposed to be IMPARTIAL?
If a person's belief is CONTRARY to your own, do you agree?
Would a BARREN area have many people in it?
Do people usually dislike their COMRADES?
Will most stores BARTER with you?
Does New Year's Day COINCIDE with Christmas?
Could a COURIER use a car?
The chemist came up with a new COMPOUND that was the most powerful glue ever invented.
She APPOINTED at me and said I was the one.
He COMPENSATED for a long time before finally making up his mind.
He is the most DUMBFOUNDED person I know. He can't add two and two.
Although the speech was both informative and ELEVATING, many people slipped out before it was over.
The suspect refused to ACKNOWLEDGE that he had done anything wrong.
They don't know English very well, so you must speak slowly and with CLARITY.
The school CONDENSED the six-month course so that now it takes a year.
We became very IMPARTIAL for him to arrive after we had been waiting for two hours.
The boy is so CONTRARY that he won't do anything the teacher asks him to do.
His efforts were completely BARREN; he had nothing to show for his work.
They were my COMRADES in the army; now I never see them any more.
He thought that getting a car in exchange for a few old chairs was a good BARTER.
The two cars arrived at the corner at the same time and COINCIDED with a loud crash.
The COURIER had to slip through enemy territory to bring the news to headquarters.

COMPOUND.deftext:
a combination, mixture 
A COMPOUND is something formed by combining different parts or ingredients. See _con-_ under Prefixes. 
"Water is a COMPOUND of oxygen and hydrogen." 
"His book is a COMPOUND of interesting facts and silly theories." 
COMPOUND _words_, such as storeroom and outside, are words that are made up of other words. 
COMPOUND is also a verb, meaning "to make a mixture." 
"The druggist COMPOUNDED the medicine out of several others." 
The verb also means simply to _add to_, _increase_. 
"Our latest attempt at a solution simply COMPOUNDED our problems."

APPOINT.deftext:
to name, designate 
To APPOINT someone is to name him to a job or a position. 
"The president APPOINTED him to be his personal secretary." 
"Jim was APPOINTED class treasurer by the teacher." 
To APPOINT is also to fix or choose a time for an event. 
"We were all there at the APPOINTED time, ready to begin work." 
An APPOINTMENT is the act of APPOINTING. 
"He opposed the APPOINTMENT of that judge to the Supreme Court." 
It is especially used to mean "an agreed-upon arrangement for a meeting." 
"They had an APPOINTMENT to eat lunch together on Thursday." 
Other forms of the word: APPOINTMENT, n.

COMPENSATE.deftext:
to make up, offset, balance; to pay, pay back 
To COMPENSATE for something is to make up for it. 
"She COMPENSATED for being unable to use her legs by getting a special car with hand controls." 
"You can't COMPENSATE for weeks of not studying by staying up and reading all night just before the exam." 
Very often COMPENSATE refers to money which is used to make up for loss or injury. 
"The company paid Sam a thousand dollars to COMPENSATE him for the injury he suffered at work." 
The noun form of COMPENSATE is COMPENSATION, which is something given, usually money, to make up for something else. 
"She had to sue to get the COMPENSATION due her for the accident." 
"He receives adequate COMPENSATION for the work he does." 
Other forms of the word: COMPENSATION, n.

DUMBFOUNDED.deftext:
amazed, astonished, puzzled 
The word DUMB has two meanings. The first is "not able to speak," _speechless_, as in the phrase "deaf and DUMB." The second is _stupid_, _dull_. DUMBFOUNDED comes from the first meaning. To be DUMBFOUNDED is to be so surprised and puzzled that you are speechless. 
"We were DUMBFOUNDED when we discovered that the treasure was missing." 
"The DUMBFOUNDED explorers could only stare in wonder at the palace they had discovered in the middle of the jungle." 
The most common mistake on the Pretest is the choice of _stupid_ as the meaning of DUMBFOUNDED—due to confusion, of course, with the second meaning of DUMB. 
Other forms of the word: DUMBFOUND, v. 
Usage: DUMBFOUNDED is also often spelled _dumfounded_.

ELEVATING.deftext:
uplifting, exalting 
To ELEVATE something is to lift it up higher. The adjective ELEVATING means "tending to lift up minds or morals." The word is almost never used about something that is physically being lifted. 
"The minister gave a very ELEVATING sermon which left everyone determined to lead better lives." 
"Alice said her visit to the art museum had been an ELEVATING experience." 
Other forms of the word: ELEVATE,v.

ACKNOWLEDGE.deftext:
to admit, confess; to recognize, accept 
You can see the word _knowledge_ in ACKNOWLEDGE. ACKNOWLEDGE has two rather different uses that deal with _knowledge_. First, to ACKNOWLEDGE something is to admit you have knowledge of it, to state or agree that it exists or has happened. 
"By signing the form, he ACKNOWLEDGED receipt of the package from the post office." 
"The criminal ACKNOWLEDGED his guilt and begged for another chance." 
Second, to ACKNOWLEDGE can mean to _take notice of_. Often the word is used about a gift or letter, to show that you have received it. 
"She sent them a short note ACKNOWLEDGING their present and thanking them for their thoughtfulness." 
ACKNOWLEDGE in this sense can also be used about responsibilities or duties to show that you recognize and accept them. 
"Bill ACKNOWLEDGED his obligation to help the poor in any way he could." 
Other forms of the word: ACKNOWLEDGMENT, n.

CLARITY.deftext:
clearness, distinctness 
CLARITY is the quality of being clear. The word can be used about things that are clear to the eye or clear to the mind. 
"The water was of such CLARITY that you could see all the way to the bottom of the lake." 
"The photograph lacked CLARITY. We couldn't make out any of the faces." 
"He presented his arguments with great CLARITY. Everyone could follow him quite easily."

CONDENSE.deftext:
to shorten, compress, abridge 
CONDENSE is related to the word _dense_, which means "packed tightly together." When something CONDENSES,it occupies less space,it becomes denser or more compact. The word is used about gases which turn into liquids. 
"The steam CONDENSED to water when it reached the cold window." 
CONDENSE is also used about written material or other kinds of information. To CONDENSE it is to make it shorter, to abridge it. 
"We don't have time to hear that long report. Could you CONDENSE it into a few sentences?" 
"They had to CONDENSE twenty hours of film into a half-hour television show." 
Other forms of the word: CONDENSATION, n.

IMPARTIAL.deftext:
fair, unbiased, just 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes. One meaning of _partial_ is "favoring one person or side more than the other." 
"He admitted that he was partial to people with a sense of humor." 
Someone who is IMPARTIAL shows no favoritism, is strictly fair and unprejudiced. 
"We want an IMPARTIAL jury. We don't want people who have made up their minds ahead of time." 
"They couldn't agree among themselves, so they brought the problem to an IMPARTIAL outsider and let him decide." 
"It's hard to be IMPARTIAL when you know someone who's involved in the case." 
Other forms of the word: IMPARTIALITY,n.

CONTRARY.deftext:
opposite, opposed; stubborn, self-willed 
Something that is CONTRARY to something else is opposed to it, is the total opposite of it. 
"You may think he is kind, but I have heard a CONTRARY opinion from someone else." 
"CONTRARY to what you might have expected, I passed the course quite easily." 
"The two candidates held CONTRARY views on many issues." 
CONTRARY can also be used about a person who is very self-willed and is always doing or saying the opposite of what people want or suggest. 
"She's a CONTRARY child. We can never get her to obey."

BARREN.deftext:
empty, fruitless 
BARREN has several uses, all of which have the idea of _empty_, _fruitless_, or _unproductive_. Land which is BARREN is no good for growing crops; it is unproductive. BARREN land is also often very difficult for people or animals to survive in, because it is too cold or windy or desert-like. BARREN trees or plants do not produce fruit or seeds. BARREN discussions have no results; they are empty and worthless. 
"We had several BARREN conversations about the matter; we never came to any conclusion about what should be done."

COMRADE.deftext:
a friend, companion 
A COMRADE is a friend or companion, someone who is loyal to you and whom you see often. 
"They became friends when they were in the fifth grade and remained COMRADES for life." 
"She was my COMRADE in school. We went everywhere together; we were almost never apart." 
"His trusted COMRADE turned against him and betrayed him." 
COMRADE is a usual form of address used by Communists. 
"COMRADE Ustinov will give a speech at the next meeting of the Communist party." 
This may lead many people to choose _enemy_ or _leader_ as a synonym for COMRADE.

BARTER.deftext:
to trade, exchange 
When you BARTER you trade goods or services for what you want instead of using money. 
"In 'Jack and the Beanstalk,' Jack BARTERED the family's cow for a handful of beans. His mother thought it was a bad trade." 
"The farmer BARTERED the use of his tractor in exchange for part of the crop." 
BARTER is also a noun meaning a _trade_ or _exchange_. 
"The doctor decided that having his cellar cleaned was a good BARTER for fixing Dan's broken arm."

COINCIDE.deftext:
to agree, be the same, correspond; to happen at the same time 
When two things COINCIDE, they are in agreement or in harmony with one another. In this sense, COINCIDE is generally used about opinions, wishes, judgments, or the like. 
"Your views on politics COINCIDE completely with my own." 
"The teacher's opinion of the boy did not COINCIDE with his parents' opinion of him." 
COINCIDE also means "to happen at the same time." 
"His arrival at the airport COINCIDED with a strike by the pilots." 
"Her birthday and mine COINCIDE." 
A COINCIDENCE is a chance occurrence of two events at the same time. 
"It was a strange COINCIDENCE that the two old friends should both be in the foreign city on business." 
Other forms of the word: COINCIDENCE, n.

COURIER.deftext:
a messenger 
COURIER comes from a French word which means to _run_. A COURIER is someone who carries messages or information. A COURIER doesn't necessarily run, but the word often suggests speed and urgency. 
"The general sent a COURIER ahead to tell the fort that more troops were on their way." 
"The COURIER arrived at the palace with the secret papers." 
"Each morning the COURIER brought them reports on the military situation."

questions.prompt: Are most people part of the POPULACE?
Would a MONUMENTAL mistake be easy to fix?
Do people usually PONDER things quickly?
Is it pleasant to be SCORNED?
Can a person earn a lot of money by being REIMBURSED?
Is it difficult to change the mind of an OBSTINATE person?
Does using the brake of a car increase its VELOCITY?
Can a riddle PERPLEX a person?
Would a prince have a distinguished PEDIGREE?
Would a picnic usually be INFORMAL?
He TIMIDLY tasted the octopus soup, and then discovered he liked it.
We used tweezers to get the SPLINTERS out of his knee.
He said that this latest problem was the PROVERBIAL straw that broke the camel's back.
His INFECTIOUS enthusiasm made everyone want to try harder.
The president could not convince the POPULACE that they should pay higher taxes.
He REVISED us again that we would be in trouble if we didn't agree.
He claimed his invention was of MONUMENTAL importance.
She PONDERED why he could be acting so strangely.
The coach feels nothing but SCORN for players who don't try as hard as they can.
We offered to REIMBURSE him, but he said he had spent too little money for us to worry about it.
The lock proved to be quite OBSTINATE, so finally we had to break the door down.
The arrows hit the target at different times because each had a different VELOCITY.
She PERPLEXED us to stop talking during class.
Since the dog had no PEDIGREE, we decided not to buy him.
The president met INFORMALLY with the two reporters this morning, but his official news conference isn't until this afternoon.

TIMID.deftext:
fearful, easily frightened, shy 
TIMID means _fearful_, _easily frightened_, _easily alarmed_. 
"He became very TIMID about riding in elevators after he was stuck in one once." 
"She looks TIMID, but she can really be quite brave when she needs to be." 
TIMID often adds to _fearful_ the idea of _shyness_. 
"He greeted his grandfather with a TIMID smile." 
"She is very TIMID at large parties." 
Other forms of the word: TIMIDITY, n.

SPLINTER.deftext:
to break up, split into pieces, break off 
A SPLINTER is a little piece of something, usually wood. 
"You're apt to get SPLINTERS in your fingers when you're working with wood." 
SPLINTER, when used as a verb, means "to break into very small pieces." 
"The wall SPLINTERED with just one blow from the heavy hammer." 
"The icicles SPLINTERED when they hit the ground." 
"He could SPLINTER a board with his bare hand."

PROVERB.deftext:
a saying, maxim, adage 
A PROVERB is a short saying that uses simple, vivid language to express some ancient wisdom. Some examples of PROVERBS are "Look before you leap," "A rolling stone gathers no moss," and "Still waters run deep." 
Something that is so well known that it has become a PROVERB is called PROVERBIAL. 
"She talked about the PROVERBIAL curiosity of a cat." 
The most common mistake for the meaning of PROVERB on the Pretest is _story_. A PROVERB is never more than a sentence or two long. It does not tell a story, but gives some general truth. 
Other forms of the word: PROVERBIAL, adj.

REVISE.deftext:
to change, correct 
REVISE basically means "to look back at." See _re-_ under Prefixes. The _vise_ part of the word is related to words like _vision_. To REVISE something is to look it over or reexamine it and make changes and corrections. 
"He REVISED his composition so that it made better sense." 
"The new figures caused them to REVISE their estimate of how much the job would cost." 
"When he started being nice to everyone we had to REVISE our bad opinion of him." 
Other forms of the word: REVISION, n.

INFECTIOUS.deftext:
catching, contagious 
To INFECT someone is to contaminate him with disease-producing germs. 
"Mosquitoes INFECTED the natives with malaria." 
"The wound became INFECTED when he didn't keep it clean." 
INFECTIOUS is an adjective from INFECT. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. An INFECTIOUS disease is one that spreads by INFECTING, like the flu or smallpox. INFECTIOUS is also used in a general way and means "spreading quickly," _catching_. 
"Yawning is INFECTIOUS. Once one person starts, everyone begins to do it." 
"He had an INFECTIOUS laugh that caused everyone to laugh with him." 
_Deadly_ is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest. INFECTIOUS diseases are communicated by germs. Some of these diseases are deadly, others are not. 
Other forms of the word: INFECT, v. INFECTION, n.

POPULACE.deftext:
the common people, the general public 
POPULACE comes from the Latin word for _people_, also the source of the words _population_ and _popular_. The POPULACE is the common people, as opposed to the wealthy or the noble. 
"The politician's plan appealed to the POPULACE, although big business was against it." 
"Although the king now had less power, the POPULACE still did not like him." 
POPULACE is also used for the entire population of a place. 
"It seemed as if the whole POPULACE of the town had turned out to greet him."

MONUMENTAL.deftext:
immense, massive, imposing 
A MONUMENT is a large building, statue, or other object which serves to keep alive the memory of a person or event. 
"The Washington MONUMENT is a great tribute to our first president." 
MONUMENTAL means "having the size and impressiveness of a MONUMENT," _massive_, _immense_. See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"It was a MONUMENTAL structure, almost a hundred stories high." 
"They made a mistake of MONUMENTAL proportions. They almost ruined the entire project." 
"Building the Panama Canal was a MONUMENTAL achievement." 
Other forms of the word: MONUMENT, n.

PONDER.deftext:
to consider, reflect, meditate, deliberate 
PONDER comes from a Latin word meaning to _weigh_. PONDER means "to weigh carefully in the mind." 
"He PONDERED the decision for a long time before acting." 
"Sally PONDERED whether to save her money or buy a new dress." 
PONDER is sometimes followed by _over_ or _on_, in which case it means to _think deeply_, to _meditate_. 
"She PONDERED over the mysteries of life." 
"He PONDERED on the importance of planning ahead."

SCORN.deftext:
to despise, feel contempt for; refuse SCORN is both a verb and a noun. To SCORN something is to despise it, to treat it or consider it with contempt. 
"Everyone SCORNED him for his laziness." 
You can also SCORN something and refuse to do it because it is worthless or beneath you. 
"Although she needs the money, she SCORNS offers of jobs as a cleaning person." 
When SCORN is used as a noun, it means "a feeling of contempt." 
"She has a great deal of SCORN for people who lie about their ages." 
Other forms of the word: SCORNFUL, adj.

REIMBURSE.deftext:
to pay back, repay 
See _re-_ and _in-1_ under Prefixes. The _burse_ part of the word is related to the word _purse_. The basic meaning of the word is "to put back into someone's purse," that is, to _repay_ someone. Usually the word is used about paying money to a person who has already had to spend some of his own. 
"The company REIMBURSED him for the money he spent on the trip." 
"We will gladly REIMBURSE you for the cost of the phone calls." 
"He bought the plane ticket himself, expecting to be REIMBURSED later." 
The most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest is _back up_. This is probably chosen because REIMBURSE sounds like _reinforce_.

OBSTINATE.deftext:
stubborn, unyielding 
OBSTINATE people do not yield to another's arguments or persuasion. They hold fast to their own ideas or plans. The word often suggests that OBSTINATE people are being unreasonable in not changing their minds or listening to others. 
"The OBSTINATE mule wouldn't move until its master fed him." 
"He OBSTINATELY refused to see a doctor until it was too late." 
Something that is OBSTINATE is not easily overcome or removed. 
"Their OBSTINATE resistance to change finally forced them to go out of business." 
"His illness was quite OBSTINATE; despite all the treatment he still didn't get better." 
Other forms of the word: OBSTINACY, n.

VELOCITY.deftext:
speed, quickness 
VELOCITY is the speed of something along a given path. 
"The car traveled at a VELOCITY of fifty miles an hour." 
"They had an instrument which measured the VELOCITY of a baseball thrown by a pitcher." 
"The wind is blowing in an easterly direction at a VELOCITY of 25 miles per hour."

PERPLEX.deftext:
to confuse, bewilder, puzzle 
To PERPLEX someone is to confuse and puzzle him. The word usually suggests a problem that worries and frustrates a person. 
"The teacher's questions PERPLEXED him until he suddenly hit upon the answer." 
"We have several PERPLEXING problems that we must somehow solve." 
"I'm PERPLEXED by your attitude. I just don't understand why you're acting this way." 
PERPLEXED is also an adjective. 
"The PERPLEXED young man didn't know which way to turn for help." 
PERPLEXITY is the state of being PERPLEXED. 
"He admitted his PERPLEXITY at the strange way she was behaving." 
Other forms of the word: PERPLEXITY, n.

PEDIGREE.deftext:
ancestry, family descent 
A PEDIGREE is the ancestry of a person or animal, or a record of that ancestry. The word usually suggests a noble or distinguished family tree. The word is especially used in reference to animals, where it stresses proof of pure breeding for many generations. 
"She insisted that any dog she bought should have a PEDIGREE." 
"They were very proud of their family's long PEDIGREE."

INFORMAL.deftext:
not formal, unofficial 
See _in-2_ under Prefixes. FORMAL means "following the rules or customs." Something which is INFORMAL is done without ceremony or great attention to the rules. 
"They held some INFORMAL discussions before starting the official meeting." 
"There was an INFORMAL investigation into the cause of the fire, but no report was ever written." 
"He gave a brief, INFORMAL talk about his trip to Europe." 
Many people think INFORMAL means _unimportant_. An INFORMAL meeting or discussion could, however, be quite important. 
Other forms of the word: INFORMALITY, n.

questions.prompt: If someone said he could run a hundred miles an hour, would most people find that CREDIBLE?
Would a LEGITIMATE excuse be made up?
Can you UNEARTH something by burying it?
Do you UNFURL a flag by rolling it up?
Would a hobo usually be PRIM?
Does a HABITUAL smoker smoke very often?
Is PUTRID food bad to eat?
Would you expect a lot of PAGEANTRY in a parade?
Is the first snowfall a HERALD of summer?
Do you ENDORSE a check by ripping it up?
Was World War II an UPRISING?
Is the North Pole ACCESSIBLE by automobile?
Their success has been so CREDIBLE that we still can't believe it.
The contest isn't LEGITIMATE: the winners have been picked already.
It took several years to UNEARTH the cause of the strange disease.
The ship set out with all her sails UNFURLED and billowing in the breeze.
He's so PRIM and proper he'd think that wrestling in the mud was the most disgusting thing in the world.
As usual he performed his HABITUAL morning exercises.
Meat will turn PUTRID if not cooked or frozen.
After a while he became bored by all the PAGEANTRY and longed for something simpler.
The development of the polio vaccine HERALDED the conquest of that terrible disease.
The mayor ENDORSED the police department's efforts to reduce crime.
The government is just too strong; an UPRISING against it would have no chance of success.
He was a PROMINENT person, always saying he would do something and never getting around to it.
He liked to MIMIC the unusual way the teacher walked.
We placed all our medicines in a place that was INACCESSIBLE to the baby.

CREDIBLE.deftext:
believable, trustworthy 
See _-able_ under Suffixes. The _cred_ part of the word comes from the Latin word for _believe_. Something which is CREDIBLE is able to be believed. 
"His explanation of why he was late was CREDIBLE." 
"His story about being captured by Martians was not very CREDIBLE." 
Someone who is CREDIBLE is trustworthy and can be believed. 
"A CREDIBLE witness says she saw him somewhere else, so I guess he didn't commit the crime." 
Many people select _true_ as the meaning of CREDIBLE on the Pretest. Something that is CREDIBLE will usually be true, but does not have to be. 
"The story was CREDIBLE, so newspapers printed it; we then found out it was a practical joke." 
Other forms of the word: CREDIBILITY, n.

LEGITIMATE.deftext:
lawful; reasonable, proper, valid 
LEGITIMATE comes from the Latin word for _law_, also the source of the word _legal_. The basic meaning of LEGITIMATE is _lawful_. 
"The court decided his claim was LEGITIMATE." 
The word is now also used rather broadly to mean _reasonable_, _logical_, _justifiable_. 
"He has a LEGITIMATE excuse for being absent"—that is, his excuse makes sense, it is justified. 
"This money should only be used for LEGITIMATE purposes." 
"He had a LEGITIMATE reason to be upset with us."

UNEARTH.deftext:
to discover, uncover, find 
See _un-_ under Prefixes. UNEARTH basically means "to take the earth covering off something." In general use, UNEARTH means to _uncover_ or _discover_ something. 
"The researcher UNEARTHED some new information about George Washington's career in the army." 
"When tracing your family's history, you may UNEARTH embarrassing things about your ancestors." 
"He UNEARTHED a plot to kill the judge."

UNFURL.deftext:
to open out, unroll, spread out 
UNFURL is used chiefly with flags, sails, and other large pieces of fabric. When you FURL a flag or sail, you roll it up. So to UNFURL a flag is to open it out or to spread it out. See _un-_ under Prefixes. 
"For the holiday, all the flags were UNFURLED." 
"In preparation for the journey, all the sails on the ship were UNFURLED and inspected for damage." 
Other forms of the word: FURL, v.

PRIM.deftext:
neat, tidy, stiffly formal 
A PRIM person is overly neat in his appearance and overly proper in his behavior. The word usually suggests someone who dislikes anything rough or vulgar. It often suggests that this is a bad quality, that the person is too concerned about his appearance and too worried about improper behavior. 
"The PRIM old lady was shocked by our ragged appearance." 
"The PRIM gentleman never went out of the house without being perfectly dressed." 
"She PRIMLY informed us that little boys were not allowed to sit on her nice clean chairs."

HABITUAL.deftext:
regular, usual, customary 
A HABIT is a fixed way of doing something. 
"He had a bad HABIT of talking with his mouth full." 
Something which is HABITUAL results from HABIT, is usual or regular. See _-al_ under Suffixes. 
"He took his HABITUAL walk after dinner." 
"She drank her HABITUAL cup of coffee in the middle of the morning." 
HABITUAL is also used about people, and means "acting by HABIT." 
"Don't believe him; he's a HABITUAL liar." 
"She's a HABITUAL latecomer; she never gets anywhere on time." 
Other forms of the word: HABIT, n.

PUTRID.deftext:
rotten, decayed, very distasteful 
Something that is PUTRID is in an advanced state of decay, so that it has a foul taste and smell. Food which is PUTRID is disgusting and distasteful. 
"They refused to eat the fish because of its PUTRID smell." 
"The meat had been left outside in the sun and turned PUTRID." 
Often PUTRID is simply used to mean _awful_, _terrible_, _vile_. 
"Ed said the movie was PUTRID—one of the worst he had ever seen."

PAGEANTRY.deftext:
grand display, splendid spectacle 
A PAGEANT is a public show or spectacle, often involving colorful floats and costumes. PAGEANTRY is the colorful, splendid display of a PAGEANT. 
"The crowning of a new king is always full of PAGEANTRY." 
PAGEANTRY is sometimes used in a bad sense, to suggest that there is nothing important beneath all the display and spectacle. 
"The play had plenty of PAGEANTRY but little else." 
Other forms of the word: PAGEANT, n.

HERALD.deftext:
to announce, proclaim, give notice of 
A HERALD was a person who made public announcements for a king. From this the word has come to be used about any person or thing that announces or signals something that is to come. 
"The clear sky in the distance was a HERALD of better weather in a few hours." 
To HERALD something, therefore, is to give public notice that it is going to happen, to _announce_ it. You can HERALD something in other ways besides speaking. 
"Thousands of posters throughout the town HERALDED the candidate's arrival." 
"The appearance of the first robin HERALDED the arrival of spring."

ENDORSE.deftext:
to approve, support, vouch for, uphold 
The _dorse_ part of the word comes from a Latin word for _back_; the word's basic meaning is "to write on the back of" something, particularly an official document or a business document. To ENDORSE a check is to write your name on the back of it in order to cash it. 
A common reason for ENDORSING a document was to indicate your approval of what was on the other side. This led to the general use of ENDORSE as a word meaning to _approve_ or _support_. 
"We ENDORSE your position on taxes." 
"Whom did they ENDORSE for president?" 
The sense of the word is that if you ENDORSE something, you would be willing to sign a statement that you approve of it. 
Other forms of the word: ENDORSEMENT, n.

UPRISING.deftext:
a rebellion, revolt 
UPRISING is made up of the words _rising_ and _up_. An UPRISING is the rising up of people in a rebellion against their government. The word is often used about small, ineffective rebellions and also about the beginnings of widespread revolts. 
"In the last five hundred years there have been several UPRISINGS of the Irish against English rule." 
"The UPRISING against the government was quickly put down by the army." 
"His kingdom was never totally peaceful; a small UPRISING was always taking place in one part or another." 
In the Pretest, many people select _riot_ as the meaning of UPRISING. The two words are close in meaning. A _riot_ is any kind of public disorder by a group of people; an UPRISING is specifically aimed against the government or those in power.

PROMINENT.deftext:
easily seen, standing out; well-known, notable, distinguished 
The basic meaning of PROMINENT is standing out, so as to be easily seen. See _pro-_ under Prefixes. 
"The huge mountain is a PROMINENT landmark in the area." 
"She has very PROMINENT cheekbones." 
When used about people, the word means _well-known_, _important_, usually in a good sense. 
"He is one of the most PROMINENT citizens of this community." 
"The town was shocked when two PROMINENT doctors were charged with murder." 
"She played a PROMINENT part in producing the show." 
Other forms of the word: PROMINENCE, n.

MIMIC.deftext:
to copy, imitate 
To MIMIC someone is to copy his speech or movements, often with the intention of making fun of him. The word usually suggests a very exact copying. 
"Sally MIMICKED the odd way her sister talked." 
"The skillful actor could MIMIC any kind of character he chose." 
A MIMIC is a person who MIMICS. 
"The clever MIMIC spoke and acted just like the famous politician." 
Many people think that to MIMIC someone is to _laugh at_ him, probably because MIMICKING often involves making fun of the person who is being MIMICKED.

LUNACY.deftext:
insanity, madness 
LUNACY is from _luna_, the Latin word for the _moon_. It used to be thought that madness was related to the changes of the moon. Thus, LUNACY is another word for _madness_, particularly spells of madness that come and go. 
"It was an act of LUNACY to go walking in the snowstorm without any clothes on." 
"Usually he was quite reasonable, but he had moments of utter LUNACY." 
A LUNATIC is a crazy person, someone affected by LUNACY. 
"Only a LUNATIC would burn down his own house." 
Other forms of the word: LUNATIC, n.

ACCESSIBLE.deftext:
approachable, easy to reach 
Anything you can reach, use, or visit is ACCESSIBLE. ACCESSIBLE usually suggests that it is not too difficult to get to the person or place it refers to. 
"This store is easily ACCESSIBLE to people coming by car or bus." 
"The boss was always ACCESSIBLE and ready to listen to complaints or new ideas." 
"We are lucky to have the library so ACCESSIBLE to us; we don't have to walk far to exchange our books." 
The opposite of ACCESSIBLE is INACCESSIBLE, which means "out of reach." 
"The librarian told her that the books were INACCESSIBLE because they were being recovered." 
Other forms of the word: ACCESS, n. INACCESSIBLE, adj.

questions.prompt: Do you go higher as you ASCEND?
Would a talking horse be UNCANNY?
Would a VIVID story be dull to read?
Can you INTERSPERSE apples with oranges?
Is a FACSIMILE generally more valuable than an original?
Is going to prison sometimes a CONSEQUENCE of committing a crime?
Is a cocker spaniel a member of the CANINE family?
Do PLACID people get angry easily?
Does it take a hundred years for a century to ELAPSE?
Would most people like their decisions to be UPHELD?
Would a grief-STRICKEN person be unhappy?
Would MONOTONOUS music be fascinating to listen to?
Has a person in prison ELUDED punishment for his crime?
The airplane fell from the sky and ASCENDED to the ground.
Her OUTLANDISH methods of teaching constantly got her into trouble with the principal.
She has an UNCANNY ability to predict the weather.
I have a VIVID picture in my mind of exactly how the room is going to look.
The governor NULLIFIED the contract with the firm because they were cheating the state.
His workday was INTERSPERSED with many chances to relax and regain his strength.
John could produce a reasonably good FACSIMILE of George Washington's signature.
When the automobile was invented, no one realized the CONSEQUENCES it would have on the American way of life.
We call them CANINE teeth because they resemble an elephant's tusks.
She put a nice PLACID pillow beneath his head to make him more comfortable.
They ELAPSED the afternoon with friends on a picnic in the woods.
The heavy rains UPHELD the game for over an hour.
The entire city was STRICKEN with the plague.
She was very MONOTONOUS with the children—always telling them jokes and thinking up games for them to play.
We ELUDED them by escaping through a secret passage.

ASCEND.deftext:
to go up, rise, climb 
ASCEND means simply to _go up_. 
"The elevator ASCENDED to the top floor." 
"They threw bags of sand out of the balloon to make it ASCEND." 
"The soldier ASCENDED through the ranks until he became a general." 
Many people confuse ASCEND with its opposite _descend_, which means to _go down_. 
"They ASCENDED the mountain in the morning, and descended it in the afternoon." 
Other forms of the word: ASCENT, n.

OUTLANDISH.deftext:
strange, bizarre, ridiculous 
See _-ish_ under Suffixes. OUTLAND is a rare word for a foreign land or country—a land that is outside your own. Something that it OUTLANDISH has a foreign or unfamiliar appearance or quality. It is strange, bizarre, exotic. 
"She dressed in OUTLANDISH clothing just to shock people." 
"He had some OUTLANDISH ideas about flying saucers." 
"They made some OUTLANDISH suggestions about how to improve television."

UNCANNY.deftext:
weird, strange, mysterious 
UNCANNY means _weird_ or _strange_. The word is applied to people, events, or feelings that are so beyond what is normal or expected that they make you feel frightened or uncomfortable. 
"He has an UNCANNY way of knowing what you're thinking." 
"That dog is so smart it's almost UNCANNY." 
"We were frightened by the UNCANNY sounds."

VIVID.deftext:
lively, spirited, intense 
VIVID comes from a Latin word meaning to _live_, also the source of English words like _survive_ and _revive_. VIVID means "full of life and freshness." The word is used about things, as well as about ideas, memories, imaginations, and the like. 
"The picture is painted in sharp, VIVID colors that make a strong impression on the eye." 
"After all these years her memories of her trip to Europe are still fresh and VIVID." 
"The author wrote a VIVID account of the battle. You almost felt as if you were there." 
"Little Billy has a VIVID imagination. He's always pretending to be a detective or an astronaut."

NULLIFY.deftext:
to make void, invalidate, negate See _-fy_ under Suffixes. The NULL part of the word means _nothing_. NULL is an adjective which means "without value or effect." It is often used in the phrase "NULL and void," which means "having no legal force." 
"The judges declared that the agreement was NULL and void." 
To NULLIFY something is to make it as if it were nothing, to take away its force, value, or usefulness. 
"The referee's decision NULLIFIED the touchdown." 
"His refusal to let us finish NULLIFIED all our work for the past month. It's as if we'd never even begun." 
Other forms of the word: NULL, adj. NULLIFICATION, n.

INTERSPERSE.deftext:
to scatter, place here and there 
See _inter-_ under Prefixes. To INTERSPERSE things is to scatter or sprinkle them between or among other things. 
"Some red balls were INTERSPERSED among the black ones." 
"She INTERSPERSED some very funny jokes in an otherwise serious speech." 
In a slightly different sense, to INTERSPERSE something _with_ other things is to supply it with these things here and there. 
"He INTERSPERSED the black balls with some red ones." 
"The book was INTERSPERSED with many beautiful pictures."

FACSIMILE.deftext:
a copy, reproduction 
Note the pronunciation. The final _e_ is sounded. 
FACSIMILE is related to the word _similar_. Both come from a Latin word meaning _like_. A FACSIMILE is an exact, or almost exact, copy of a book, painting, letter, or the like. 
"He printed a FACSIMILE of the Declaration of Independence that was identical in every detail with the original." 
"She wore a dress that was a close FACSIMILE of an expensive Paris design." 
The most common mistake on the Pretest is to choose _original_ as the meaning of FACSIMILE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. A FACSIMILE is made from an original, but it is not the original itself.

CONSEQUENCE.deftext:
an effect, result; importance, value 
A CONSEQUENCE is the effect or result of something that has gone before. 
"His success was a direct CONSEQUENCE of his hard work." CONSEQUENCE often suggests a bad or undesired result. 
"If you steal this, you'll have to accept the CONSEQUENCES when you are caught." 
"He didn't consider all the CONSEQUENCES of his thoughtless behavior." 
In a different sense, CONSEQUENCE means importance, particularly with regard to the results that may come about from something. 
"His refusal to come was of no CONSEQUENCE. We had a good time anyway." 
"She is a woman of great CONSEQUENCE in her community. Nothing is done without her approval." 
Other forms of the word: CONSEQUENTIAL, adj.

CANINE.deftext:
of or relating to dogs 
CANINE means "of or like a dog." 
"A human's CANINE teeth are pointed, like a dog's teeth." 
"He followed his older brother around all day with CANINE devotion"—that is, he followed him like a dog following its master. CANINE is also a noun, meaning _dog_ or "member of the dog family." 
"Poodles, collies, and terriers are all CANINES." 
"The fox is the only CANINE that can climb a tree." 
The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is _cat_. The word which means "of or like a cat" is _feline_, not CANINE.

PLACID.deftext:
peaceful, calm, tranquil 
PLACID means "free from disturbance," _calm_, _untroubled_. 
"Not the slightest ripple disturbed the PLACID surface of the lake." 
When used about people, PLACID means "having a peaceful nature," and sometimes suggests a person who is _too_ calm and lacking in feeling. 
"She was so PLACID that not even the roar of the jet planes bothered her." 
_Soft_ and _weak_ are both sometimes chosen as the meaning of PLACID. They are both close, but not quite the same as _peaceful_, _calm_, _untroubled_. They might be chosen because of a confusion of PLACID with _flaccid_, which means _weak_, _flabby_. 
Other forms of the word: PLACIDITY, n.

ELAPSE.deftext:
to pass, slip by, glide by 
ELAPSE is almost always used about time. It means simply to _pass_, to _go by_. 
"Twenty seconds ELAPSED between the two shots"—that is, the shots came twenty seconds apart. 
"He returned after six months had ELAPSED." 
ELAPSE should not be confused with the similar verb _lapse_, which can be used about time, but it is more commonly used to mean "to fall into error" or "to go out of existence." You can say "The insurance policy _lapsed_"; it doesn't make sense, however, to say "The insurance policy ELAPSED."

UPHOLD.deftext:
to support, approve 
UPHOLD is made up of the two words _hold_ and _up_. UPHOLD means just that: to _hold up_ or _support_. UPHOLD can be used about physical things like a roof, but it is generally used about ideas, decisions, or beliefs. 
"The lower court's decision in the case was UPHELD by the higher court." 
"He tried to UPHOLD his family's good reputation." 
"I do not UPHOLD actions which are dangerous to oneself or others." 
_Put off_ is the most frequently marked wrong answer on the Pretest, probably because one meaning of _hold up_ is to _delay_.

STRICKEN.deftext:
wounded, afflicted, overcome 
STRICKEN comes from the word _strike_. Someone who is STRICKEN with something has been _struck_ or _struck down_ by it. The word is usually used about illness, sorrow, misfortune, or the like. 
"She was STRICKEN with a terrible disease." 
"Several soldiers lay STRICKEN on the battlefield." 
"After the flood the Red Cross aided the STRICKEN families." 
_Panic_-STRICKEN means "overwhelmed with great fear." 
"The _panic_-STRICKEN people fled from the huge monster." 
STRICKEN is also used in other phrases like _conscience_-STRICKEN and _grief_-STRICKEN.

MONOTONOUS.deftext:
unchanging, boring, tedious, repetitious 
See _-ous_ under Suffixes. The _mono_ part of MONOTONOUS comes from the Greek word for one. A _monologue_ is a speech for one person; a _monocle_ is an eyeglass worn in one eye only. The _ton_ part of the word comes from the word _tone_. Something that is MONOTONOUS has only one tone; it doesn't vary at all, and therefore it is boring and uninteresting. 
"The scenery was rather MONOTONOUS; there was nothing but cornfields as far as you could see." 
"The book was impressive at first, but after a while its heavy style became rather MONOTONOUS." 
"She quickly became bored with the MONOTONOUS work on the assembly line in the factory." 
Other forms of the word: MONOTONY, n.

ELUDE.deftext:
to escape, evade, slip away, avoid 
To ELUDE someone is to avoid or evade him, usually by means of cleverness or quickness. 
"The criminal managed to ELUDE the police by hiding in the trunk of a car." 
"The halfback ELUDED several tackles with his clever moves." 
Things or ideas can ELUDE you, usually by being very difficult or hard to see. 
"The answer ELUDED Bob. No matter how hard he tried he couldn't quite think of it." 
"The change she made in the room was so small that it ELUDED my notice." 
Other forms of the word: ELUSIVE, adj.

This plan is rather FUTILE; I really think we can accomplish something with it.

He is an ATROCIOUS mayor; he hasn't done anything to make this a better city.
Her heavy makeup CAMOUFLAGED the scars on her face.
They wanted to ENLIGHTEN people about the poor conditions in the prison.

INITIATIVE.deftext:
a first step, introductory action 
To INITIATE something is to begin it, to set it in motion. An INITIATIVE is the first step or move designed to start a series of events. To do something "on your own INITIATIVE" means that you take this first step without being told to. To "have the INITIATIVE" means that you are in a position to take the first step. 
INITIATIVE is also used for the readiness and the ability to INITIATE actions or projects, particularly if they are difficult or dangerous. 
"He was a man of great INITIATIVE. He saw what needed to be done and did it." 
Other forms of the word: INITIATE, v.

LAX.deftext:
not strict, loose, careless, negligent 
Someone or something that is LAX is not strict or severe enough, is careless or negligent. 
"He was very LAX about doing his homework on time." 
"He got away with it because the rules were LAX." 
Sometimes LAX is used in the sense of _loose_, "not firm or tense." 
"He had a very LAX handshake." 
The noun from LAX is LAXITY. 
"She blamed the increase in teenage crime on the LAXITY of modern parents." 
Other forms of the word: LAXITY, n.

RETORT.deftext:
a reply, sharp answer 
A RETORT is a sharp or witty answer to something that has just been said. 
"He gave a quick RETORT to the fellow's insult." 
"She couldn't think of a RETORT strong enough to show how angry she was." 
"His clever RETORTS made people laugh, but also got him into trouble." 
RETORT is also a verb. 
"'It's none of your business,' Jack RETORTED." 
"He RETORTED that she had no one to blame but herself."

SHACKLE.deftext:
a chain, iron ring 
SHACKLES are _chains_ or _iron rings_ that are put around a person's arms or legs to keep him from moving. 
"They kept the prisoner in SHACKLES." 
When SHACKLE is used as a verb, it means "to put SHACKLES on," to _chain_. 
"The convict was SHACKLED to a large post." 
SHACKLE is also used in a broader sense for anything that prevents freedom of thought, action, or progress. 
"Unless you can throw off the SHACKLES of your ignorance you will never be successful." 
Usage: SHACKLE is usually used in the plural.

TRANSACT.deftext:
to carry out, conduct 
TRANSACT means to _carry on_ or _do_. The word is usually used about business. 
"They TRANSACTED all their business in the morning." 
"It is impossible to TRANSACT business with a fool." 
TRANSACTION is the noun from TRANSACT. A TRANSACTION is a business deal. 
"Many of the company's TRANSACTIONS are with foreign firms." 
In the Pretest, _change_ is often chosen as the meaning of TRANSACT, perhaps because TRANSACT looks like _transform_, which means to _change_.

ATTIRE.deftext:
clothing, clothes, dress 
ATTIRE is another word for _clothing_, especially fancy or splendid clothing 
"They were dressed in their best holiday ATTIRE." 
"His dirty jersey and ragged pants were not proper ATTIRE for the restaurant." 
ATTIRE is also a verb, meaning to _clothe_ or _dress_. 
"For her wedding, she was ATTIRED all in white." 
_Appearance_ is often chosen as the meaning of ATTIRE. Your clothing is part of your appearance, but ATTIRE only has to do with your clothing, not your entire appearance. 
Usage: ATTIRE is a literary word, and would be used more often in writing than in speech.

COMPEL.deftext:
to force 
To COMPEL means to _force_. The word suggests strong pressure or authority being used on a person to do something. 
"The blinding rain COMPELLED us to stop driving and pull over to the side of the road." 
"His serious illness COMPELLED him to resign from his job." 
"She felt COMPELLED to warn him of the danger involved in the experiment." 
"Her brilliant play COMPELLED the crowd's attention." 
COMPELLING is the adjective from COMPEL and means "demanding attention, respect, or admiration." 
"There are COMPELLING reasons why you must agree to the plan immediately." 
"The novel was so COMPELLING that I was unable to put it down until I finished it." 
Other forms of the word: COMPELLING, adj.

EXCRUCIATING.deftext:
agonizing, extremely painful 
EXCRUCIATING is related to the word _crucify_. EXCRUCIATING means _almost unbearably painful_, as if someone were driving nails through you. 
"The pain from his broken shoulder was EXCRUCIATING for a couple of days until the bones began to heal." 
"She suffered EXCRUCIATING embarrassment whenever she had to stand up and recite in front of the class." 
"Sometimes I think nothing is more EXCRUCIATING than a toothache."

FINITE.deftext:
limited, having boundaries 
FINITE comes from the same Latin word as _finish_ and _final_. All have to do with _ends_ or _ending_. FINITE means "having an end," _limited_. 
"We cannot keep paying them forever; we have only a FINITE amount of money." 
Note that this does not mean we have a small amount of money. It simply means that we don't have an unlimited amount of money. 
"We should be able to find him; it's a big city, but the number of people in it is still FINITE." 
The opposite of FINITE is INFINITE, _endless_, _unlimited_. See _in-2_ under Prefixes. 
"We can do anything we want; the possibilities are INFINITE." 
"Some people believe that the universe is INFINITE; others believe it is FINITE."

FUTILE.deftext:
useless, ineffective, fruitless 
FUTILE means _of no use_, _in vain_. An action or plan that is FUTILE cannot have the result that is hoped for. 
"He made a FUTILE attempt to push the car by himself, then gave up." 
"Realizing it was FUTILE to fight any longer, the enemy surrendered." 
"It is FUTILE to argue with him. He never changes his mind." 
The noun from FUTILE is FUTILITY, which means _uselessness_. 
"Despite the FUTILITY of our actions, we kept trying to unlock the door." 
"I explained to him the FUTILITY of trying to start a fire with wet matches." 
Other forms of the word: FUTILITY, n.

MUTINOUS.deftext:
rebellious, ready to revolt, difficult to control 
A MUTINY is a rebellion or revolt against people in authority. The word is particularly applied to soldiers or sailors who turn against their officers. MUTINOUS is the adjective from MUTINY. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. Someone who is MUTINOUS is rebelling, or is ready to rebel, against the orders of his superiors. 
"The soldiers became MUTINOUS over the rotten food they were forced to eat." 
MUTINOUS is also used in a broader sense to mean "difficult to control," _unruly_. 
"The teacher found it impossible to get the MUTINOUS child to sit still and stop pestering everyone." 
Other forms of the word: MUTINY, n.

SUPERLATIVE.deftext:
supreme, excellent 
See _super-_ under Prefixes. Something which is SUPERLATIVE is of the highest quality; it is extremely great or excellent. 
"It was a SUPERLATIVE dinner. It may have been the best I have ever had." 
"Her SUPERLATIVE paintings have won many prizes." 
"We thought it had been a SUPERLATIVE achievement to finish the job on time."

ATROCIOUS.deftext:
terrible, dreadful, wicked, cruel 
ATROCIOUS means _extremely wicked_ or _barbaric_. 
"Everyone was shocked by the ATROCIOUS crime." 
"The company treated its workers ATROCIOUSLY—the conditions in the factory were almost inhuman." 
In a slightly different sense, ATROCIOUS also means _extremely bad_, _awful_. 
"The movie was simply ATROCIOUS—I left after ten minutes." 
"He made an ATROCIOUS error that cost the company millions." 
The most commonly selected incorrect answer is _remarkable_. This may be due to confusion with the word _precocious_. _Precocious_ means "having a talent which usually appears in an older person." A _precocious_ child would be remarkable; he wouldn't usually be ATROCIOUS. 
Other forms of the word: ATROCITY, n.

CAMOUFLAGE.deftext:
to disguise, mask, conceal 
CAMOUFLAGE is both a verb and a noun. In the military, CAMOUFLAGE is the use of paint, tree branches, netting, or other materials to give a false appearance to something like a tank or a gun position. Thus, to CAMOUFLAGE something is to disguise it in order to hide it or to deceive someone. 
"The color of many animals is a natural CAMOUFLAGE that keeps larger animals from seeing them." 
"His constant smile CAMOUFLAGED his real feelings."

ENLIGHTEN.deftext:
to inform, instruct 
The original meaning of ENLIGHTEN was "to supply with light." Now the word is only used in the sense "to give knowledge"—that is, to free someone from the "darkness" of misunderstanding or ignorance. 
"I know nothing about his background. Could you ENLIGHTEN me?" 
"We tried to ENLIGHTEN him as to the nature of the problem, but he wouldn't listen." 
Someone who is ENLIGHTENED is free from ignorance and superstition. 
"The boss took a very ENLIGHTENED approach in dealing with his workers. He treated them as equals and never threatened them." 
The most commonly selected incorrect answer is _amuse_, possibly because the _light_ part of ENLIGHTEN is thought to mean _not serious_. 
Other forms of the word: ENLIGHTENED, adj. ENLIGHTENMENT, n.

questions.prompt: Would a duke belong to the ARISTOCRACY?
Does polishing spoons give them LUSTER?
Would a school SUPERINTENDENT be in charge of schools?
Is a ZEALOUS worker likely to be fired?
Is a SHIRKER a good person to work with?
Are COMPASSIONATE people likely to feel sorry for those who are not as lucky as they are?
Are speakers who RAMBLE usually interesting to listen to?
Should a person feel REMORSE for stealing money?
Is there a CHRONOLOGY to the events of your life?
Is it FEASIBLE to play football and read at the same time?
Do you use your INTELLECT when you take a test?
Does the better team always PREVAIL?
He started out as a poor farmer, but when he died he was a member of the ARISTOCRACY.
His drunken behavior took away from the LUSTER of the event.
Dave SUPERINTENDED to go to the party, but he just couldn't make it.
Her ZEAL for doing good works made everyone admire her.
He tried to SHIRK the blame for the disaster, but we wouldn't let him.
He had a COMPASSION for tennis. He would play it all day if he could.
She RAMBLED quickly and directly to her destination.
The STENCH of garlic on his breath was overwhelming.
Everyone felt genuine REMORSE and satisfaction when we finally won the championship.
When the new editor took over, he changed the FORMAT of the newspaper.
She used the dates at the top to arrange the letters in CHRONOLOGICAL order.
She was a very FEASIBLE woman; she inherited a lot of money when she was young.
The president called in several great INTELLECTS to advise him.
We PREVAILED on him to say a few words to the class.
He SHREWDLY hinted that if we didn't want the house, there were plenty of other people who did.

ARISTOCRACY.deftext:
the nobility, upper class 
ARISTOCRACY comes from Greek words meaning "rule by the best." The basic meaning of ARISTOCRACY is "a form of government in which the best people rule." In common use the word refers to the highest social class of a country, the noble families who are accustomed to ruling and having power. 
"As members of the ARISTOCRACY, the noblemen were entitled to many things that the common people could not have." 
"The United States has never had an ARISTOCRACY or ruling class." 
Other forms of the word: ARISTOCRAT, n. ARISTOCRATIC, adj.

LUSTER.deftext:
brightness, sheen; brilliance, glory 
LUSTER is the soft glow of light reflected off a polished surface. 
"She rubbed the table with a special oil to increase its LUSTER." 
From this, LUSTER has come to mean _brightness_ in the sense of _glory_, _brilliance_, _distinction_. 
"The mere presence of the famous woman added LUSTER to the occasion." 
"This act of heroism added further LUSTER to his already great reputation." 
Other forms of the word: LUSTROUS, adj.

SUPERINTEND.deftext:
to manage, oversee, look after 
To SUPERINTEND something is to have charge of it, to supervise the management of it. 
"He was chosen to SUPERINTEND the running of the store." 
"There was only one person to SUPERINTEND the entire building." 
A SUPERINTENDENT is a person who manages something like a building or a school. 
"If your heat goes off, call the building's SUPERINTENDENT immediately." 
Other forms of the word: SUPERINTENDENT, n.

ZEAL.deftext:
eagerness, passion, enthusiasm 
ZEAL is eager devotion to a cause, religion, idea, or the like. 
"Despite the ZEAL of his supporters he lost the election." 
"His ZEAL for teaching young children is unmatched." 
"In his ZEAL to improve humanity he sometimes goes too far and offends people." 
Someone who feels a great deal of ZEAL for a cause or goal is ZEALOUS. 
"Jane is a ZEALOUS defender of the rights of poor people." 
"The policemen were ZEALOUS in enforcing the new law." 
Other forms of the word: ZEALOT, n. ZEALOUS, adj.

SHIRK.deftext:
to avoid, dodge 
SHIRK means "to try to escape from doing" something, usually because of laziness, fear, or simple dislike of the work to be done. 
"He would like to SHIRK his homework, but he knows he has to do it." 
"I cannot SHIRK the responsibility for my mistake." 
A person who is lazy and tries to avoid doing a fair share of the work is called a SHIRKER. 
"SHIRKERS always try to get somebody else to do their work for them." 
Other forms of the word: SHIRKER, n.

COMPASSION.deftext:
pity, sympathy 
COMPASSION is a feeling of pity. If you have COMPASSION, you understand and share in the suffering or pain which someone else feels. 
"She had COMPASSION for suffering animals, so people brought her their sick and unwanted cats and dogs." 
"He gave the beggar a quarter, not out of COMPASSION, but simply to get rid of him." 
Someone who feels COMPASSION is COMPASSIONATE. 
"William gave Sally a COMPASSIONATE glance when her mother scolded her for being late again." 
Other forms of the word: COMPASSIONATE, adj.

RAMBLE.deftext:
to wander, roam 
To RAMBLE is to wander about, to go from place to place, without any special aim. 
"They RAMBLED across the countryside, stopping whenever they liked." 
The word is often applied to talking and writing that goes on and on without any point. 
"He had a tendency to RAMBLE when he talked. He just couldn't stick to the subject." 
"She RAMBLED on about her garden until everyone had fallen asleep."

STENCH.deftext:
a stink, foul odor 
A STENCH is a strong, foul odor, like the odor of something rotting. 
"The meat created quite a STENCH after it was left out in the hot sun all day." 
"No one could stand the STENCH of the tobacco he used in his pipe."

REMORSE.deftext:
regret, repentance 
REMORSE is deep, bitter guilt and sorrow for having done wrong. It comes from a Latin word meaning "to bite again" and suggests a guilty feeling that is gnawing away at your conscience. 
"I immediately felt REMORSE for having yelled at her." 
"The criminal showed no REMORSE for the murder." 
"Their REMORSE didn't seem genuine. I don't think they're a bit sorry." 
Other forms of the word: REMORSEFUL, adj. REMORSELESS, adj.

FORMAT.deftext:
arrangement 
FORMAT is related to the word _form_. The FORMAT is the general physical arrangement of something, particularly of a book or magazine. 
"They changed the FORMAT of the magazine so that it was bigger and had more pictures." 
"They hoped the new FORMAT of the books would make them easier to read." 
The word can also be used about other kinds of arrangements, like that of a television show. 
"The idea behind the show is good, but the FORMAT is all wrong."

CHRONOLOGY.deftext:
time order 
The _chron_ part of CHRONOLOGY means _time_. It is found in the word _chronograph_ (a stop watch), as well as in the words _chronic_ and _chronicle_. A CHRONOLOGY is the order in which a particular series of events occurred. 
"The detective tried to establish the CHRONOLOGY of the events that led up to the murder." 
A CHRONOLOGY is also a table or list which organizes things according to the time at which they occurred. Finally, CHRONOLOGY is the science that tries to establish accurate dates for past events. 
CHRONOLOGICAL is the adjective from CHRONOLOGY. To put things "in CHRONOLOGICAL order" is to arrange them in the order of their time. 
"He listed Shakespeare's plays in CHRONOLOGICAL order." 
Other forms of the word: CHRONOLOGICAL, adj.

FEASIBLE.deftext:
possible, practicable; likely; suitable Something which is FEASIBLE is able to be done, is possible. 
"It was hardly a FEASIBLE plan, considering the costs involved." 
"The most FEASIBLE solution is not necessarily the fairest one." 
FEASIBLE is also sometimes used to mean _logical_ or _likely_. 
"His excuse seemed FEASIBLE enough." 
The word can also mean "capable of being dealt with successfully," _suitable_. 
"They chose the most FEASIBLE route they could find for the new road." 
"Is sunlight a FEASIBLE source of energy?" 
Other forms of the word: FEASIBILITY, n.

INTELLECT.deftext:
mind, understanding, reasoning 
INTELLECT is related to the word _intelligent_. The INTELLECT is the reasoning power of the mind, as opposed to its feelings and instincts. 
"He has a great INTELLECT, but he's not a very pleasant person to know." 
"My INTELLECT tells me that this is the right decision, but I wish it could be otherwise." 
INTELLECT is also used to mean "a person with great reasoning powers." 
"The finest INTELLECTS in the country were present at the conference." 
INTELLECTUAL is an adjective formed from INTELLECT. It means "having to do with the INTELLECT." 
"He preferred INTELLECTUAL pursuits, such as reading and chess, to sports." 
Other forms of the word: INTELLECTUAL, adj., n.

PREVAIL.deftext:
to win, triumph; to be widespread; to persuade 
To PREVAIL _over_ or _against_ means to _win_ or _gain victory_. 
"We PREVAILED over our enemies." 
Sometimes the word is used without _over_ or _against_. 
" 'Justice will PREVAIL' means that justice will finally win out." 
PREVAIL can also mean "to be common or widespread." 
"After weeks of rioting, a feeling of calm now PREVAILS in the city." 
To PREVAIL _on_ or _upon_ someone is to persuade him, often with some difficulty. 
"We finally PREVAILED upon him to tell us the secret." 
"She PREVAILED on her father to let her use the car." 
Other forms of the word: PREVAILING, adj. PREVALENT, adj.

SHREWD.deftext:
clever, keen, astute 
A SHREWD person has a great deal of cleverness and sound judgment, especially in practical matters. 
"He's a SHREWD judge of talent. He rarely makes a mistake about actors." 
"Several SHREWD businessmen bought all the land before oil was discovered there." 
SHREWD often contains a sense of trickiness in its meaning. 
"The SHREWD salesman knew just how to get people to buy the worthless stock." 
People often think SHREWD means _unpleasant_, possibly because SHREWD is often used in a negative way about people who are tricky or dishonest. SHREWD might also be confused with the word _shrew_, which means "a bad-tempered woman."
